Anderssonb, S.L.T. Anderssonb, G. Centia, R.K. Grassellil, M. Sanatib, F. Trifiroa 'Dept. of Industrial Chemistry and Materials, Univ. of Bologna, V.le Risorgimento 4, 40136 Bologna, Italy w , Fax. (+39-51) 6443680, e-mail CICATAL@B01FCC.C1NECA.ITlw 'Dept. of Chemical Technology, Chemical Center, Univ. of Lund, P.O. Box 124, 22100 Lund, Sweden `Dept. of Chemistry, Georgetown University, 20057 Washington, DC, USA (Received 2 November 1993; revised 14 February 1994; accepted 14 February 1994) Abstract Unsupported vanadium antimonate catalysts with Sb/V ratios of 1 and 5 and samples with the latter ratio supported on alumina were studied in toluene and propane ammoxidation to benzonitrile and acrylonitrile, respectively, and were characterized by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS ) analysis before and after catalytic tests. Activity data for toluene ammoxidation suggest that excess antimony with respect to the stoichiometric amount required for forming the VSb04 rutile phase affects the dispersion of the latter phase giving smaller particles. Vanadium sites are involved both in the activation of toluene and in the insertion of nitrogen in this reaction, whereas antimony does not play a specific role in the reaction mechanism. In propane ammoxidation, on the other hand, due to a higher reaction temperature with respect to toluene (500 vs. 370), free vanadia on the surface of the catalyst has a negative influence on the selectivity because it promotes the conversion of ammonia to nitrogen, decreasing the surface nitrogenous species required for the selective formation of acrylonitrile. Excess antimony is thus necessary for completing the reaction between antimony and vanadium oxides, but antimony also participates in the reaction mechanism. In propane ammoxidation, in fact, XPS data show that both vanadium and antimony sites are reduced. Tentatively, vanadium sites are involved in the activation of propane, while antimony sites insert nitrogen. The differences between the toluene and propane ammoxidation mechanisms are interpreted to be primarily related to the different reaction temperatures. Key words: acrylonitrile; antimony; benzonitrile; propane ammoxidation; toluene ammoxidation; vanadium; Xray photoelectron spectroscopy *Corresponding author. 'Present address: Central Research Laboratory, Mobil, Princeton, New Jersey, USA 0926-860X/94/$07.00 1994 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved SSD10926-86OX (94)00030-U O A. Andersson et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 113 (1994) 43-57 1. Introduction Vanadium antimonate based catalysts have drawn considerable attention in recent years for their catalytic behaviour in propane ammoxidation. A large number of patents have been published claiming vanadium antimonate as the active phase, but only limited information is available in the literature about its characterization (see refs. [ 1-ll] and references therein). On the other hand, the good catalytic behaviour of V-Sb--0 based catalysts in the ammoxidation of alkylaromatics has been known for several years [5], even though also in this case few data have been reported about the structure/activity relationship. It is known that vanadium and antimony form a rutile VSb04 phase with the same structure and characteristics as the well-known FeSb04 active phase for propene ammoxidation where antimony is the active element [6]. In addition, similarly to the optimal composition of iron antimonate catalysts in propene ammoxidation, vanadium antimonate catalysts for propane ammoxidation are more selective when excess antimony is present (Sb:V > 1, the stoichiometric value for formation of the VSb04 rutile phase). Furthermore, it has been shown for vanadium antimonate samples with excess vanadia that some vanadium oxide can also be present supported on VSb04 crystals [ 4 ] . The structural and reactivity analogies between vanadium antimonate and iron antimonate samples thus may suggest a main role of antimony in the catalytic ammoxidation of hydrocarbons, but, on the other hand, vanadium oxide supported on alumina or Ti02 is a well known active and selective system for the ammoxidation of alkylaromatics [5,7-9] . It is therefore not clear whether antimony, vanadium or both participate in the reaction mechanism and which phase (VSb04, Sb204, vanadium oxide supported on these phases) or cooperation of phases is catalytically active in the ammoxidation reactions. An analysis of the structure/activity relationship in this system, especially when associated with surface characterization of the samples before and after the catalytic reaction, can clarify these problems. Furthermore, it must be taken into account that although there are reasonable analogies in the mechanisms of propane and alkylaromatics ammoxidation, the modalities of activation of the hydrocarbon certainly will be different. A comparison of the reactivity of these two hydrocarbons on the same samples gives therefore useful further indications about the role of the different elements or phases in determining the catalytic behaviour. The aim of the present research was to compare the activity of vanadium antimonate catalysts in propane and toluene ammoxidation and to characterize the surface of the samples by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) before and after the catalytic tests in order to obtain some information about the nature of the active elements in this catalytic system and about the differences in the selective transformation of the two hydrocarbons. 2. Experimental V-Sb oxides were prepared according to patent indications [ 1-l] by a slurry method which involved refluxing for at least 8 h (usually 24 h) an aqueous solution containing NH4V03 and Sb203 (in such a ratio as to obtain a Sb/V atomic ratio of 1.0 or 5.0) and A. Andersson et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 113 (1994) 43-57 45 alumina or Al(OH)3 followed by evaporation of the solvent in a rotavapor and drying at 100 overnight. The resulting solid was then heat treated at 350 for 4 h followed by a further step at 650 (6 h) (after intermediate grinding and mixing of the sample) in air. In the case of the sample with alumina, the amount of this phase in the final sample was 70 wt.-%. The sample without vanadium was prepared using the same procedure and composition (amount of antimony and alumina) as that of samples with vanadium, but omitting the addition of this component during the slurry step. Different methods of addition of the aluminium component were used. The samples, called VSbSlAI(1) and SblAI (see Table I for nomenclature), were prepared by adding commercial A1203 (140 m2/g) in the form of powder, whereas in the preparation of the sample called VSbSIAI(2), Al(OH)3 was added during the slurry step. Sample VSb5/Al(3) was prepared using a different procedure involving the precipitation of a mixed hydroxide gel containing V, Sb and Al and an organic component (carboximethylcellulose). The gel was then dried and calcined similarly to the other samples. The catalytic tests of propane ammoxidation were made in a fixed-bed quartz flow reactor with a catalyst charge of about 5 g (40O mesh) diluted with quartz microspheres. An online gas-chromatographic system equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) (6 m long Porapak QS column for the analysis of propene, propane, acetonitrile and acrylonitrile) and a thermoconductivity detector (a 3 m long Carbosieve-II column for OZ, N2, CO, NO and COZ separation) were used for the analysis of reagents and reaction products, whereas HCN formation and ammonia conversion were determined by titration after adsorption in 0.1 M NaOH solution. Further details on the apparatus for the catalytic tests and on the analytical procedure have been previously reported [2-4]. Preliminary tests as well as calculations indicate that mass and heat transfer limitations may be considered negligible under our experimental conditions. Homogeneous gas-phase reactions were also checked and found to be negligible under our experimental conditions. The catalytic tests of toluene ammoxidation were carried out at 370 in a glass plugflow reactor at differential conditions (toluene conversion 3-5%). Carbon oxides were formed as the main by-products. Over 0.17-0.22 g of catalyst (35-100 mesh), diluted with quartz of the same particle size, a total gas flow of 186 cm3 (STP) /min was passed. The partial pressures of toluene, oxygen and ammonia were 0.77, 11.4 and 2.84 kPa, respectively. Nitrogen was used as an inert gas. Reaction products were analyzed on a gas chromatograph equipped with an FID detector and a methanizer unit for the conversion of separated carbon monoxide and carbon dioxide to methane before detection. The reactor and analysis arrangement were the same as previously described [ 10] . The XPS measurements were performed with a Kratos XSAM 800 instrument. Mg Ka X-ray radiation was used. The slit width was set at 80and the analyzer was operated at 40 eV pass energy and at high magnification. Peak intensities are expressed as the relative area above a linear base line. To estimate the V 2P3,2 intensity, the contributions from Mg Kc13,4 satellites of the OAS and Sb 3d5,2 lines were subtracted. This was done by subtracting the spectrum for Sb60, 3, normalized at the O, 5 position. For A1203 supported samples, however, the spectrum for Sb-0/A1203 was subtracted. For quantification purposes, instrumental sensitivities for the various core lines were measured for the pure oxides: A1203, V205, Sb203 and were A1 2p = 0.13, V 2P3,2 =1.86, Sb 3d3,2 = 5.70. Charging effects were corrected for by adjusting the Au 4f peak, of gold deposited on separate samples, to a position 46 A. Andersson et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 113 (1994) 43-57 at 84.0 eV. For the rA1203 support, the A1 2s and Al 2p binding energies (BE) were measured and found to be 119.4 and 74.6 eV, respectively. These values were constant for all Sb-V-0/A1203 samples and are therefore not reported separately. Details on the other characterization techniques used have been previously reported [ 2-4 ] . 3. Results and discussion 3.1. Characteristics of the samples The best patented catalysts for the reaction of propane ammoxidation have a considerable excess of antimony (a V:Sb atomic ratio of around 1:5) and are usually supported on alumina (an amount of alumina of about 50-70 wt.-%, see refs. [ 1-4] and references therein). Similar catalytic compositions, even though with higher V:Sb ratios, have also been reported for the ammoxidation of alkylaromatics [ 5 ] . Four samples were thus selected in order to study the reactivity of vanadium antimonate catalysts and compare their behaviour in propane and toluene ammoxidation. The first two samples (VSb l and VSb5) are unsupported and have a V:Sb atomic ratio of 1:1 and 1:5, respectively. The third sample has a V:Sb ratio of 1:5, but is supported on alumina [VSb5/Al(1) ] . The amount of alumina in this sample is 70% and both the composition and the preparation method are very similar to those of patented samples for propane ammoxidation. The last sample (SblAl) was prepared in a similar way, but without adding vanadium, in order to obtain better discrimination between the effects of vanadium and antimony. All samples were calcined at 650 in air according to patent indications. Table 1 reports the surface area of these samples and summarizes the code name and composition. The characteristics of these samples are also summarized in Table 1. X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis of VSbl shows the presence of only VSb04, whereas the additional presence of a-Sb204 was detected in VSb5. Also reported in Table 1 are the relative amounts of VSb04 in these two samples determined by quantitative XRD using a calibrated mixture with Ti02 (anatase) as the internal standard. The relative amount estimated in the case of the hypothesis of complete reaction of vanadium to form the VSb04 phase is also given. In agreement with the XRD data, infrared (IR) characterization of these two samples shows the presence of VSb04 and VSb04+a-Sb204 in VSbI and VSb5, respectively, but also indicates that the reaction of VSb04 formation is not complete in VSbI. In fact, a well defined band centred at 1020 cm-' shows the presence of unreacted VS +-oxide, probably amorphous and therefore undetectable by XRD. There is considerable reduction in the amount of this V5+ species after the catalytic reaction, but a weak band centred at 995 cm-' can still be seen. It should be remembered that monolayer V5+ species on Ti02 (anatase) are characterized by an IR band centred at 995 cm-', whereas in samples with a higher vanadium coverage, where XRD analysis shows the presence of crystalline V205, a sharp band is found centred at about 1020 cm'. It is thus possible to conclude that in fresh VSbl some unreacted amorphous V205 exists which disappears after the catalytic reaction, leaving, however, a lower amount of V5+ species spread on the surface of the vanadium antimonate crystals. In the fresh VSb5 a band is also observed at around 1020 cm-', but it is much weaker as compared to the analogous band for MI. The excess antimony, therefore, enhances the formation of the VSb04 phase. In VSb5 after the catalytic tests, a similar situation to that discussed above for VSbl is found, even though the relative intensity of the band centred at 995 cm-' is lower. It should also be noted that XRD characterization of VSb5 indicates that the mean diameter of the VSb04 crystals (around 100-200 A) is much less than that of a-Sb204 crystals (800-1000 A) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM) studies show that the VSb04 crystals have a much more spongy appearance than the a-Sb204 crystals. The former phase therefore contributes mainly to the surface area of the VS65 sample notwithstanding the lower relative amount. In the sample supported on alumina [VSb5/AI(1) ] only very weak lines of the VSb04 rutile phase were detected, without any presence of crystalline a-Sb204, even for the higher calcination temperatures (up to 900). Similarly, in the sample without vanadium (Sbl Al), no XRD bands connected to the presence of antimony oxides were observed in the samples calcined up to 900, and the only bands present were those of a rutile phase connected with the reaction of antimony with alumina (AlSb04). IR characterization of these samples does not give useful information due to the presence of stronger skeletal vibrations of alumina, but Raman characterization of the samples confirms the analogy between supported and unsupported vanadium antimonate catalysts. VSb5/Al(2) shows strong analogies to VSbS lAl (1) , but the surface area is slightly lower. VSbS lAl (3) , on the other hand, has a surface area similar to unsupported samples. Also XRD data of the latter sample are different from the other two with alumina. In the third sample bands indicative of well-crystallized VSb04 and a-Sb204 phases can be detected, whereas weak and broad lines for only the VSb04 phase are detected in the other two samples with alumina. This 48 A. Andersson et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 113 (1994) 43-57 suggests that it may be better to consider the third VSb5/A1 sample as a mixture of V-SbO phases and (low surface area) alumina rather than as V-Sb-0 phases supported on (higher surface area) alumina as for the first two VSb5/A1 samples. Additional data about the structure and composition of these samples have been previously reported [4]. 3.2. Surface characterization The XPS characterization of the samples after toluene ammoxidation is reported in Table 2 together with some reference values for antimony and vanadium oxides. In order to show more clearly the change in Sb/V surface ratio as a function of the bulk value, XPS data for two other unsupported vanadium antimonate samples with Sb:V atomic ratios of 0.8 and 2.6 (VS60.8 and VSb2.6, respectively) are also given. Reported in Fig. I is an example of the XPS spectra covering all of the V 2p, O Is and Sb 3d binding energy region (Fig. la) with an expansion of the V 2P3/2 signal obtained by subtracting the spectrum for Sb,0,3 (see Section 2) (Fig. lb). The Sb/V surface atomic ratio of unsupported samples does not increase linearly with the bulk ratio when the bulk value exceeds 1. This, however, can be understood by taking into consideration the difference in the crystal sizes between the VSb04 and a-Sb204 phases mentioned above which leads to a poor dispersion of excess antimony and thus to an apparently lower surface antimony content. In agreement, better dispersion was found in the samples supported on alumina with a Sb:V surface ratio closer to the bulk value (Table 2), the only exception being VSbSlAI(3). The latter sample, however, must be considered as a mixture of V-St-O phases and alumina as discussed above and thus cannot be considered as being formed of V-Sb-0 phases supported on alumina. The V/Al ratio is, however, similar to that for VSbIAI(I), and this excess vanadium may be present as dispersed vanadium oxide. In VSbSlAI(1) and VSb5/Al(2) samples, on the other hand, the interaction of excess antimony with alumina avoids the formation and growing of Sbz04 crystals even for higher calcination temperatures. The surface Sb:V ratio is thus found to be close to the bulk value, suggesting that there is no surface enrichment of either of the two components on the surface of VSb04. The analysis of Sb and V valence states is quite difficult since the shifts in Sb 3d3,2 and V 2P3,2 binding energies (BE) are relatively small. It is about 0.8 eV for Sb3+-Sbs+ and about I eV for V4+-Vs+. In the latter case it is further complicated by the overlap of V 2P3,2 with A1 Ka3,4 satellites of O is and Sb 3d5,z. The less well defined envelope obtained after subtraction of these features in combination with low intensity implies that resolution of the spectra into components for the two valence states is of limited value. A rough estimate is obtained from the BE values. In the case of antimony, the curve resolution is reasonably accurate, but there is a lack of suitable reference samples. It has been reported that commercially available Sb205 is in general Sb60,3 or antimonic acid [ 11 ] . Crystalline SbZ05 was not available to us, since high oxygen pressures are required for its synthesis [ 12,13 ] . The Sb205 (Aldrich) was amorphous according to XRD data, and only weak and 50 A. Andersson et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 113 (1994) 43-57 broad lines from a-Sb204 could be identified. Titration with iodine indicated its composition to be about 90% Sb20, and 10% Sb204. Both a-Sb204 [ 14,15] and P-Sb204 [ 16] contain two crystallographically different antimony atoms that may be ascribed to Sb3+ and SbS+. The Sb 3d3,2 BE of a-Sb204 is measured to be 540.2 eV, which is only 0.2 eV higher than the BE value for Sb203 (see caption of Table 2), whereas Sb6013 and Sb205 give a BE value of 540.7 and 540.8 eV, respectively. The BE shifts are in agreement with earlier XPS data [ 17-20] . It is thus difficult to interpolate the Sb 3d3,Z BE value to obtain a precise value for the mean Sb valence state, but the Sb3+ /SbS+ ratio maybe roughly estimated by fitting the Sb 3d3,2 line with two components, taken as the natural curve forms of Sb203 and Sb6013. The ratio so obtained was the value corrected for the mean Sb valence state in Sb6013. The Sb 3d3,2 BE value measured for the various samples ranged from 540.2 to 540.6 eV and the V 2P3,2 from 516.5 to 517.1 eV, which indicates the presence of Sb3+, Sb5+, V4+ and V5+ (and possibly also of V3+) surface species in all samples. The general tendency derived by comparing fresh and used samples containing aluminium is that upon use in toluene ammoxidation both antimony and vanadium are slightly reduced, which is seen by their lower BE values (Table 2). The same reductions were observed after use in propane ammoxidation. For unsupported samples, on the other hand, only the vanadium is reduced in toluene ammoxidation while reduction of both vanadium and antimony occurs in propane ammoxidation [4]. Fig. 2, for example, shows the deconvolution of the Sb 3d3,2 signal of VSbl and VSb5 before and after propane ammoxidation which indicates the reduction of SbS+ to Sb3+. Catalytic tests Toluene ammoxidation Compared in Table 1 is the catalytic behaviour of the prepared catalysts in toluene ammoxidation to benzonitrile. VSb 1 and VSbS show a similar rate of benzonitrile formation expressed per unit surface area and a similarly high selectivity (above 90o) in spite of the fact that the former sample consisted of mainly VSb04, while the latter sample was a mixture of VSb04 and a-Sb204. This can be explained by the fact that in VSbS the VSb04 particles are smaller than the a-Sb204 particles and are also smaller than the VSb04 particles in VSbl. In fact, whereas the selectivity in benzonitrile formation from toluene depends only slightly on the conversion, an significant dependence was found of the selectivity to acrylonitrile in propane ammoxidation. The selectivity to acrylonitrile (ACN) passed trough a maximum for a propane conversion in the 20-40% range (Fig. 5). For both supported and unsupported alumina catalysts a reduction of vanadium and antimony occurred in propane ammoxidation [4], suggesting that both elements participate in the reaction mechanism. The presence of the side vanadia phase supported on vanadium antimonate crystals has a considerable effect on the catalytic behaviour. The comparison of the catalytic behaviour of VSbI and VSb5 (Fig. 6) shows that the former sample is much less selective than the latter due to the higher formation of carbon oxides. This is probably connected with the higher rate of side ammonia conversion to nitrogen on this catalyst [ 4,22 ] , which leads to a lower surface coverage of nitrogenous species. For iron antimonate catalysts [ 23 ] it has also been shown that when the surface is not populated to a considerable extend by nitrogenous intermediates, combustion tends to dominate. In toluene ammoxidation, due to the higher rate of hydrocarbon activation and less severe reaction conditions, the rate of side conversion to nitrogen of surface nitrogenous intermediates is much lower and thus the presence of the vanadia side phase affects the catalytic behaviour only slightly, whereas in propane ammoxidation its role is much more critical. Conclusions Propane and toluene ammoxidation on unsupported and alumina supported V-Sb-0 based catalysts show various analogies, evidencing common aspects in their mechanism of transformation. However, there are also some important differences. Propane ammoxidation, when compared with that for toluene, shows enhanced transformation of adsorbed nitrogenous species to nitrogen. This is due to the higher reaction temperature needed and the lower surface coverage with hydrocarbon intermediates. Activity measurements suggest that nitrogen formation is catalyzed by a separate vanadia phase, the presence of which is thus deleterious for propane ammoxidation. The main role of antimony in excess of the stoichiometric amount needed to form the VSb04 rutile phase is to prevent the formation of a separate vanadia phase and to promote the creation of an active VSb04 surface [ 24] . XPS data show that both the vanadium and antimony in VSb04 participate in the mechanism of propane ammoxidation, while vanadium seems to be the most critical element of the two for toluene ammoxidation. The difference can be explained by the higher reaction temperature needed for propane ammoxidation (500 vs. 370) which causes increased reactivity of oxygen bonded to antimony. Furthermore, in propane ammoxidation five hydrogen atoms are abstracted compared with three in toluene ammoxidation, evidencing for propane ammoxidation a more demanding catalyst reduction-reoxidation cycle with a possible role for antimony sites. The present indication that in toluene ammoxidation over vanadium antimonate it is the vanadium sites that are involved in both toluene activation and the insertion of nitrogen agrees with the well known fact that pure vanadium oxide, both in supported and unsupported form, is active and selective for toluene ammoxidation to benzonitrile in the range 350-400 [ 5,7-9 ] . At these temperatures the rate for conversion of ammonia to nitrogen is low. In correspondence with the mechanism of toluene transformation, it is reasonable to suggest that the role of vanadium sites in propane ammoxidation is that of activation of hydrocarbon, whereas antimony sites as a consequence of the high reaction temperature participate in the insertion of nitrogen. The present results clearly demonstrate that the dispersion of VSb04 on alumina is affected by the method of preparation. The use of A1203 [ VSb5 /Al (1) ] and Al (OH) 3 [VSb5/Al(2) ] give comparatively homogeneous samples that are selective for the formation of intermediate propene and acrylonitrile. Coprecipitation with V, Sb and Al [VSb5/ A1(3) ] gives a heterogeneous sample that is enriched with vanadia at the surface, and gives a higher yield in combustion products. A. Unsupported vanadium antimonate catalysts with Sb/V ratios of 1 and 5 and samples with the latter ratio supported on alumina were studied in toluene and propane ammoxidation to benzonitrile and acrylonitrile, respectively, and were characterized by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis before and after catalytic tests. Activity data for toluene ammoxidation suggest that excess antimony with respect to the stoichiometric amount required for forming the VSbO4 rutile phase affects the dispersion of the latter phase giving smaller particles. Vanadium sites are involved both in the activation of toluene and in the insertion of nitrogen in this reaction, whereas antimony does not play a specific role in the reaction mechanism. In propane ammoxidation, on the other hand, due to a higher reaction temperature with respect to toluene (500°C vs. 370°C), free vanadia on the surface of the catalyst has a negative influence on the selectivity because it promotes the conversion of ammonia to nitrogen, decreasing the surface nitrogenous species required for the selective formation of acrylonitrile. Excess antimony is thus necessary for completing the reaction between antimony and vanadium oxides, but antimony also participates in the reaction mechanism. In propane ammoxidation, in fact, XPS data show that both vanadium and antimony sites are reduced. Tentatively, vanadium sites are involved in the activation of propane, while antimony sites insert nitrogen. The differences between the toluene and propane ammoxidation mechanisms are interpreted to be primarily related to the different reaction temperatures.
